metadata.title: Introduction: AI Coding Course for Senior Engineers

slides.title: AI Coding Course for Senior Engineers
slides.subtitle: Operator Training for Production AI Agents

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: Welcome to operator training for AI coding agents. This course assumes you're already an experienced engineer who's tried AI tools and hit friction. We're not here to teach you how to code—we're teaching you how to operate AI agents as precision tools in production environments.
speakerNotes.discussion: Quick poll: How many of you have tried AI coding assistants and gotten frustrated within the first few weeks?
speakerNotes.context: By 2025, AI coding assistants are production-standard. The technology works, but most developers don't know how to operate them effectively. That's what this course fixes.
speakerNotes.transition: Let's start by addressing the core problem most engineers face...

slides.title: The Problem: Wrong Mental Model
content: Most engineers treat AI agents like junior developers
Waiting for them to 'understand', fixing line-by-line
Fighting context limits, endless iteration cycles
The technology works—the operating model doesn't

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: You've probably experienced this: prompting an AI assistant, getting mediocre output, manually fixing it, repeating endlessly. The instinct is to treat the agent like a junior developer—explain things clearly, review their work, mentor them. That's the wrong model.
speakerNotes.discussion: What's the most frustrating thing you've experienced with AI coding tools? Chances are it stems from expecting human-like understanding.
speakerNotes.context: In production, companies that succeed with AI don't treat agents as teammates. They treat them as programmable tools that require operator expertise.
speakerNotes.transition: So if AI agents aren't teammates, what are they?

metaphor.label: Marketing Speak
content: Your AI pair programmer
Understands your codebase
Thinks like a developer
Learns from feedback

reality.label: Technical Reality
content: CNC machine for code—requires operator training
Processes text context through token prediction
Executes deterministic tool calls (Read/Edit/Bash)
Has no memory—operates on current context only

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: Marketing sells AI as a teammate who 'understands' your code. Reality: it's a CNC machine. Just like a CNC operator programs precise movements into a machine, you program precise tasks into an agent. The machine doesn't understand metallurgy—it executes operations accurately when configured correctly.
speakerNotes.discussion: Ask: What does this reframing change about how you'd approach using these tools?
speakerNotes.context: CNC operators don't expect the machine to learn or improvise. They plan cuts, set parameters, validate output. That's exactly what effective AI operators do: plan tasks, craft precise prompts, validate with tests.
speakerNotes.transition: Now let's look at what this course actually teaches...

slides.title: What This Course Is
content: Operator training: Plan-Execute-Validate methodology
Production techniques: grounding, sub-agents, parallel execution
Real codebases, real scenarios, no toy examples
Built using the same techniques taught here

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: This is systematic operator training. You'll learn the three-phase workflow used in production: Plan tasks agent-appropriate, Execute with precise prompts and sub-agents, Validate using tests as guardrails. Every lesson uses real codebase scenarios—no trivial demos.
speakerNotes.discussion: Note the meta-level insight: this entire course was developed using these techniques. The content, structure, examples, even the podcast version—all agent-assisted using the methodology you're about to learn.
speakerNotes.context: Companies shipping AI-assisted features fast all follow variations of this methodology. It's not about prompt templates—it's about understanding principles and building operator judgment.
speakerNotes.transition: Equally important to clarify what this course isn't...

left.label: Not Included
content: AI theory or transformer internals
Copy-paste prompt templates
Beginner programming tutorials
Magic solutions that eliminate skill requirements

right.label: What We Focus On
content: Enough internals to operate effectively
Principles that adapt to any codebase
Advanced techniques for experienced engineers
Systematic methodology requiring judgment and skill

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: We're not teaching AI theory—just enough internals to operate effectively. We're not providing prompt templates to copy—those break when contexts change. And we're definitely not replacing fundamentals. You still need to know architecture, design patterns, and system design. This course teaches you how to amplify those skills with AI agents.
speakerNotes.discussion: Ask: Why do you think prompt templates don't work reliably? Because they're context-dependent. Understanding principles lets you craft the right prompt for any situation.
speakerNotes.context: Beginners trying to use AI agents without fundamentals produce broken code fast. Experienced engineers using these techniques ship reliable features faster. There's no shortcut around foundational knowledge.
speakerNotes.transition: So who exactly is this course for?

slides.title: Target Audience
content: 3+ years professional engineering experience
Already tried AI tools and hit frustration points
Need to move faster without sacrificing quality
Care about production-readiness, not demos

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: You're the target audience if you've been engineering professionally for at least 3 years, already tried AI coding tools and gotten frustrated, and need to actually ship production code faster. This isn't for people who want to skip fundamentals or generate demo code for interviews.
speakerNotes.discussion: Show of hands: How many of you started using AI tools enthusiastically, then stopped because the output quality wasn't reliable?
speakerNotes.context: The frustration wall typically hits around week 2-4 of using AI tools. You've gotten some quick wins, then hit cases where the agent hallucinates, breaks tests, or produces subtly incorrect code. That's exactly when you need operator training.
speakerNotes.transition: Let's talk about what you'll actually gain from this course...

slides.title: What You'll Gain
content: Onboard to unfamiliar codebases 5-10x faster
Refactor complex features reliably with test-driven validation
Debug production issues by delegating analysis to agents
Know when to use agents vs when to code yourself

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: After this course, you'll onboard to new codebases dramatically faster using agentic research. You'll refactor complex features with confidence because tests validate agent output. You'll debug production issues by delegating log and database analysis. Most importantly, you'll develop judgment about when agents add value versus when you should just write code directly.
speakerNotes.discussion: Ask: What would 5-10x faster codebase onboarding mean for your work? How about cutting refactoring time in half while improving code quality?
speakerNotes.context: The judgment piece is critical. Effective operators don't use agents for everything—they recognize high-value use cases like codebase research, boilerplate generation, and test writing, versus low-value cases like trivial one-line changes.
speakerNotes.transition: Now let's preview the course structure...

slides.title: Course Structure: Three Modules
content: Module 1: Understanding the Tools—mental models, architecture, context mechanics
Module 2: Methodology—prompting, grounding, workflow design, sub-agents
Module 3: Practical Techniques—onboarding, planning, testing, reviewing, debugging
Sequential consumption recommended—each module builds on previous concepts

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: The course has three modules. Module 1 builds your mental model—how agents actually work under the hood. Module 2 teaches the core methodology—prompting principles, grounding techniques, sub-agent delegation. Module 3 is practical application—onboarding, planning, testing, reviewing, debugging. Go sequentially—later concepts depend on earlier ones.
speakerNotes.discussion: Emphasize that hands-on exercises are mandatory. Reading alone won't build operator skills—you need to practice on real codebases.
speakerNotes.context: The methodology isn't theoretical. It's distilled from production use at companies successfully shipping AI-assisted features. Every technique has been battle-tested.
speakerNotes.transition: Before we wrap up, there's one more thing worth mentioning about this course's development...

slides.title: This Course Practices What It Teaches
content: Entire curriculum developed using agent-assisted techniques
Content structure, lessons, examples—all planned and refined with AI
Podcast versions generated via Claude Code + Gemini API
Validation: if these techniques built this course, they'll work on your codebase

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: This course practices what it teaches. The entire curriculum—content structure, lesson progression, code examples—was developed using the same agent-assisted techniques you'll learn. The podcast versions were generated using Claude Code and Gemini API, including the AI-generated voices and script. This isn't marketing—it's validation. If these techniques can produce production-grade training material, they're robust enough for your codebase.
speakerNotes.discussion: Ask: What does it tell you that this course itself was built using these techniques? It demonstrates they're not just for code—they work for any complex, structured content creation.
speakerNotes.context: Transparency matters. When using AI-assisted techniques in production, you should document it. Not because there's anything wrong with it, but because reproducibility and verification matter in engineering.
speakerNotes.transition: Let's summarize the key takeaways before we dive into Module 1...

slides.title: Key Takeaways
content: Agents are CNC machines
Operator training beats prompt templates
Plan-Execute-Validate is the methodology
Judgment determines when to use

speakerNotes.talkingPoints: Remember these core principles: AI agents are CNC machines requiring operator training, not teammates needing mentorship. Operator training—understanding principles and building judgment—beats memorizing prompt templates. The methodology is Plan-Execute-Validate, applied systematically. And most importantly, effective operators develop judgment about when agents add value versus when to code directly.
speakerNotes.discussion: Ask: Which of these takeaways challenges your current approach to AI tools the most?
speakerNotes.context: If you internalize just one thing from this intro, make it the CNC machine metaphor. It reframes everything else.
speakerNotes.transition: Ready to start? Let's begin with Module 1: Understanding the Tools.
